review.title: Weakly Supervised Scalable Audio Content Analysis
review.abstract: Audio Event Detection is an important task for content analysis of multimedia data. Most of the current works on detection of audio events is driven through supervised learning approaches. We propose a weakly supervised learning framework which can make use of the tremendous amount of web multimedia data with significantly reduced annotation effort and expense. Specifically, we use several multiple instance learning algorithms to show that audio event detection through weak labels is feasible. We also propose a novel scalable multiple instance learning algorithm and show that its competitive with other multiple instance learning algorithms for audio event detection tasks.

sections.heading: 2. MULTIPLE INSTANCE LEARNING AND AED
sections.text: In supervised learning labels for all instances are known during the training and the learner tries to find decision boundaries that can best separate these designated instances. As we are involved in detecting the presence or absence of an event in a record, we will basically deal with binary cases where labels are either − 1 or 1. Instances that belong to the target class are described as positive (+ 1 label) and those that do not belong to the target class as negative (-1). Multiple learning can be described as a generalised form of supervised learning. Here, labels are not known for every instance, instead labels for a bag full of instances are known. A bag is described as positive if at least one instance in it is labelled as negative. This implies that all instances in a negative bag can be labelled as negative.

sections.heading: 2.1. Audio Feature Representation
sections.text: The first step is the parameterization of all audio recordings by basic features such as Mel Cepstra coefficients (MFCC); the MFCC characteristics for all available audio are then used to learn a code book through clustering algorithms (e.g. Kmeans); then, for each given recording, their MFCC vectors are quantified to a cluster in the code book; and finally, a histogram is used that represents the number of MFCC vectors that belong to each cluster as a feature representation for recording. We need a form of feature representation that can represent robust short-term audio segments (instances of pockets). sections.heading: 3. MIL ALGORITHMS
sections.text: The first two algorithms, referred to as miSVM and MISVM [20], are based on the Support Vector Machine (SVM). The standard SVM algorithm was modified to work in the MIL domain. Although a few other SVM formulations for the MIL domain were proposed [18], miSVM and MISVM were the first SVM formulations for MIL and were well suited for a variety of MIL tasks. Our third MIL algorithm is a more general approach called miFV, which attempts to solve the scalability problem in the MIL paradigm. Our proposed novel MIL method is also based on the idea behind the MIL. We offer a brief description of these methods.

sections.heading: 5. DISCUSSIONS AND CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This paper dealt with scalability issues in the detection of audio events. We addressed scalability issues on two fronts. Firstly, this work is directly related to the detection of audio events where acquiring heavily labeled data is extremely difficult and expensive, which imposes limitations on the vocabulary of audio events and the amount of training data available for audio events. The aim of this work was to provide a way to address these scaling problems. Our claim is that obtaining weak labels is much easier than obtaining strong labels. We then successfully demonstrated that multiple instance learning frames can be used to learn from weakly labeled data. Secondly, the scalability of the MIL algorithm even for AED tasks. Standard MIL algorithms such as miSVM and MISVM can be used to detect thousands of instances of scalability problems themselves, because the number of data instances can be multiplied by thousands.
